Description: A prolific meteor shower known for its strong peak usually producing around 40 meteors per hour.
The Lyrids is an annual meteor shower that peaks in April. It is known for fast and bright meteors with the potential for fireballs.
This meteor shower is associated with Halley's Comet and it produces a higher-than-average rate of meteors reaching about 60 per hour.
The Delta Aquarids is a moderate meteor shower that can produce about 20 meteors per hour at its peak.
One of the most popular meteor showers the Perseids are known for producing up to 60 meteors per hour during peak activity.
The Draconids are a minor meteor shower usually producing about 10 meteors per hour. It is associated with the comet 21P/Giacobini-Zinner.
The Orionids are a medium-strength meteor shower that produces about 20 meteors per hour. They are associated with Halley's Comet.
The Taurids are a long-running meteor shower with a low rate of meteors (5-10 per hour). However they are known for producing bright and slow-moving fireballs.
The Leonids are an annual meteor shower associated with the comet Tempel-Tuttle. They produce about 15 meteors per hour at their peak.
Considered one of the best meteor showers the Geminids can produce up to 120 meteors per hour. They are known for colorful and bright meteors.
The Ursids are a minor meteor shower usually producing about 5-10 meteors per hour. They are associated with Comet 8P/Tuttle.
